qas.question: What year did Igot led a Rus attack on Constantinople?
How large was the fleet that attacked the Bithynian coast along with the Pecheneg allies?
Why did the attack by the Rus go so well on the coast at the start?

answers.text: Byzantine fleet was occupied with the Arabs

qas.question: What did the emperor of Byzatine do to some of the old retired ships to help fight the Rus?
What year did Oleg make peace with Constantinople?
How many sailing ships attacked the Bithyian coast?

plausible_answers.text: Byzantine fleet was occupied with the Arabs

qas.question: Why id the attack by the Rus go so poorly on the coast at the start?
How was the large group of retired ships outfitted?
What year was the Rus fleet defeated?

context: In <a0_0><b4_0>941<b4_0/><a0_0/>, Igor led another major Rus' attack on Constantinople, probably over trading rights again. A navy of <a1_0><b5_0>10,000<b5_0/> vessels<a1_0/>, including Pecheneg allies, landed on the Bithynian coast and devastated the Asiatic shore of the Bosphorus. The attack was well-timed, perhaps due to intelligence, as the <a2_0><b6_0>Byzantine fleet was occupied with the Arabs<b6_0/><a2_0/> in the Mediterranean, and the bulk of its army was stationed in the east. The Rus’ burned towns, churches, and monasteries, butchering the people and amassing booty. The emperor arranged for a small group of retired ships to be <a3_0>outfitted <b7_0>with Greek fire throwers<b7_0/><a3_0/> and sent them out to meet the Rus’, luring them into surrounding the contingent before unleashing the Greek fire. Liutprand of Cremona wrote that "the Rus', seeing the flames, jumped overboard, preferring water to fire. Some sank, weighed down by the weight of their breastplates and helmets; others caught fire." Those captured were beheaded. The ploy dispelled the Rus’ fleet, but their attacks continued into the hinterland as far as Nicomedia, with many atrocities reported as victims were crucified and set up for use as targets. At last a Byzantine army arrived from the Balkans to drive the Rus' back, and a naval contingent reportedly destroyed much of the Rus' fleet on its return voyage (possibly an exaggeration since the Rus' soon mounted another attack). The outcome indicates increased military might by Byzantium since <b8_0>911<b8_0/>, suggesting a shift in the balance of power.
